official-title.#text:
To amend title XIX of the Social Security Act to provide
		  for increased price transparency of hospital information and to provide for
		  additional research on consumer information on charges and out-of-pocket
		  costs.

cosponsor.#tail:
) introduced the following
			 bill; which was referred to the

short-title.#text:
Health Care Price Transparency
			 Promotion Act of 2013

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

header.#text:
Increasing the
			 transparency of information on hospital charges and making available
			 information on estimated out-of-pocket costs for health care services

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Title XIX of the Social Security Act

text.#text: in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, to require disclosure of information on hospital charges, to
				make such information available to the public, and to provide individuals with
				information about estimated out-of-pocket costs for health care
				services;

text.#text:
provide that the
				State will establish and maintain laws, in accordance with the requirements of
by inserting after

header.#text:
Increasing the transparency of information on hospital
		  charges and providing consumers with estimates of out-of-pocket costs for
		  health care services

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
are
				that the laws of a State must—

text.#text: The requirements referred to in
in accordance with

require the
				disclosure of information on hospital charges; and

provide for access
				to such information; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, require the provision of a statement of the estimated
				out-of-pocket costs of an individual for anticipated future health care
				services.

text.#text: in accordance with
The laws of a State must—

require
				disclosure, by each hospital located in the State, of information on the
				charges for certain inpatient and outpatient hospital services (as determined
				by the State) provided at the hospital; and

provide for timely
				access to such information by individuals seeking or requiring such
				services.

The laws of a State must require that, upon
				the request of any individual with health insurance coverage sponsored by a
				health insurance issuer, the issuer must provide a statement of the estimated
				out-of-pocket costs that are likely to be incurred by the individual if the
				individual receives particular health care items and services within a
				specified period of time.

Nothing in this section shall be construed
				as—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
to establish uniform standards for the State laws
				required by

text.#text: Except as provided in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
title XIX of the Social
			 Security Act

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
determines
			 requires State legislation (other than legislation appropriating funds) in
			 order for the plan to meet the additional requirements imposed by the amendment
			 made by
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Secretary of Health and Human Services

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, the State plan shall not be regarded as failing to
			 comply with the requirements of such title solely on the basis of its failure
			 to meet these additional requirements before the first day of the first
			 calendar quarter beginning after the close of the first regular session of the
			 State legislature that begins after the date of the enactment of this Act. For
			 purposes of the previous sentence, in the case of a State that has a 2-year
			 legislative session, each year of such session shall be deemed to be a separate
			 regular session of the State legislature.

Research on

Director of the
			 Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section
			 901(b)(1)(D) of the Public Health Service Act

quote.#tail: ) shall conduct or support research, pursuant to

header.#text:
Research on
			 information valued and used by consumers

text.#text:
the types of
			 information on the charges, and out-of-pocket costs, for health care services
			 that individuals find useful in making decisions about where, when, and from
			 whom to receive care;

how the types of
			 information valued by individuals for making such decisions vary by whether
			 they have health benefits coverage and, if they do, the type of such coverage
			 they have, such as traditional insurance, health maintenance organizations,
			 preferred provider organizations, and high deductible plans coupled with health
			 savings accounts; and

ways in which such
			 information may be made available on a timely basis and in easy-to-understand
			 form to individuals facing such decisions.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
on the results of such research
			 not later than 18 months after the date of the enactment of this Act, together
			 with recommendations for ways in which the Federal Government can assist the
			 States in achieving the objective specified in
